channel.title: How to make money from dice games?
channel.description: If the odds are really 1:1, how do you gain money by hosting? Are there any tricks you can do?

item.title: How to make money from dice games?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Davidi2:

Yea I understand that, and I agree. Your chances aren’t 50%. But how would that mean you lose more money, when your chances of winning and losing money are still the same (even if they are less than 50%)

Perhaps saying it as losing more money was a bad way of putting it. But what I’m saying is, just like a 1:1 system, even if the number of wins to loses eventually averages out, you may end up losing more than you win because of the idea you most likely bet more and more everytime you win and lose to try and make the big bucks.

Give, for example, a system where, regardless of the odds, you always bet the same amount. You should always end up with the same money stack after a theoretical even number of scenarios. I’m talking more along the lines of the betters downfall than anything else.

I probably seem super inconsistent here, lol. I’m just saying, I never took stats. I just figured this all out on my calculator one day, don’t crucify me. D:

Read full topic
item.source: How to make money from dice games?

item.title: How to make money from dice games?
item.dc:creator: @reyx7 reyx7
item.description:
@reyx7 wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:21, topic:416085”][quote author=reyx7 link=topic=518024.msg3763972#msg3763972 date=1317081514]

Oh, if that’s what you’re talking about then I don’t care or disagree. Considering all context was about making money, I was talking about your chances of making against your chances of losing money.
(And in the other thread it sounded like you were saying people shouldn’t dice because they had a higher chance of losing than winning, which is what I disagreed with)

Absolutely not. They just don’t have a 1:1 chance, which is why they lose more than they gain in the long run. According to the law of averages, they won’t end up with the same number of loses as wins.
[/quote]Gah… how about we do this (and end the ‘not wins’ vs ‘losses’ stuff, and talk strictly about making money):
Wins (win money):Ties (nothing):Losses (lose money)
X:Y:X

Are you trying to say that number of times you lose money will be greater then the times you win money (X > X)?

Why would use the same variable to represent something different.

It’s X:Y:Z, where X=Z and X>Y, Z>Y

Mathematically, it is X:Y:X though. Anyway, you have the same chance of winning as losing, but that’s not a 50% chance. That’s all I was getting at.

Edit: Unless you apply the law of averages, but don’t do that.[/quote]

Oh in the case of the odds of winning, yes that makes sense, in which X>Y<X. I don’t see why we can’t just pinpoints the odds of a tie at 1/12, as that is your only odds of it occurring.

Read full topic
item.source: How to make money from dice games?

item.title: How to make money from dice games?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

drubrkletern:

There is a pattern though, after a wave of low numbers, high chance of an number that is higher

PRNGs are based on patterns, but they are so arbitrary it would take a lot of genius to actually derive some sort of logical pattern, especially when your account alone is probably only receiving a mere fraction of the output of the PRNG on the particular machine the server which you are connected to is running upon.

Also noting, there should be no misconception that odds change between rolls. If you roll a 2, you have the same odds of rolling another 2, and another, and so on.

Read full topic
item.source: How to make money from dice games?

item.source: How to make money from dice games?

item.title: How to make money from dice games?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:13, topic:416085”]Oh, if that’s what you’re talking about then I don’t care or disagree. Considering all context was about making money, I was talking about your chances of making against your chances of losing money.
(And in the other thread it sounded like you were saying people shouldn’t dice because they had a higher chance of losing than winning, which is what I disagreed with)[/quote]

Absolutely not. They just don’t have a 1:1 chance, which is why they lose more than they gain in the long run. According to the law of averages, they won’t end up with the same number of loses as wins.

Noting to people: looking up how dicing odds works is very beneficial. For example, it is statistically favorable to roll a 7 above all other combinations of 2 6-sided dice rolls.

rip4d:

Dice are rigged. After a set of low numbers, they’re set to roll higher; and vice versa. This is why you sometimes see people winning nearly every dice game they play.

I wouldn’t agree with that. I could be a real arse and talk about how imperfect pseudo-random number generation is, but in the long run, it is pseudo random after all. It’s the best we can do. (and in further technicality, it’s probably more random than actually rolling dice in real life)

Read full topic
item.source: How to make money from dice games?

item.title: How to make money from dice games?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:8, topic:416085”]ODDS ARE 1:1 BECAUSE THERE ARE TWO PEOPLE INVOLVED HERE, YOU HAVE A DISCREPANCY IF EACH PERSON HAS LESS THAN 50% (not counting 10% for the host)

if x < 50
2x < 100

???

EDIT - Talking about duels of course, not 55x2 or whatever[/quote]

But it isn’t a simple ratio lol. That’s the part you aren’t understanding.

According to this website, “Odds are the ratio between the number of winning possibilities and the total number of all remaining possibilities.” This is why I said it isn’t a simple ratio. It’s a ratio between the winning possibilities and the total number of all remaining possibilities. As I have said in countless posts earlier, the remaining possibilities are not only losing. This is probability theory.

Read full topic
